title: Muhurtha Kaal Undruthal
description: The start of the wedding rituals
content: Four to five days before the wedding, both the bride and groom’s families conduct the first pooja that officially starts off the wedding rituals. The top of a bamboo cane is decorated with mango leaves. The priest performs puja, and the bride and groom's close relatives apply manjal (turmeric) and kungumam (vermilion) at five different spots on the cane. It is tied up at the entrance of the house and is referred to as 'Muhurtha kaal.' This notifies those in the neighborhood that a marriage will take place at this house.

title: Kalyanam Soluthal - Proclamation of Marriage
content: Following Muhurtha Kaal Undruthal, the immediate family of the bride and groom formally invite the grandparents, aunts, and uncles to the wedding.

title: Kumbuduthal - Offering to God and Ancestors
content: It is customary to start by praying to God and ancestors before any good event. The family prays that the marriage should go well without any hindrance and that the bride and groom be blessed with the 16 virtues, including Knowledge, Longevity, Dexterity, Youth, and Perseverance.

title: Kudi Aaki Unuthal - Gathering
description: The start of family gatherings and feasts
content: Two days before the wedding, the extended family starts gathering at the wedding house and formal feast festivities kick off.

title: Mulaipaari Poduthal - Sprouting
description: Symbolic rituals for growth and prosperity
content: The groom’s family soaks navadaniyam (nine seeds) to sprout, symbolizing the couple’s growth. They also build a straw stack representing a fort, which the couple steps over after tying the knot.

title: Thumbu Pidithal
content: The day before the wedding, two married women draw a temple pattern on the wall using thread and rice batter. This ceremony is known as Thumbu Pidithal and represents inviting the presence of God.

title: Kaluthiru Vankuthal and Korthal
description: Preparation of the traditional wedding jewelry
content: The groom’s family collects the Kaluthiru (a unique gold necklace) from the bride’s family and prepares it for the wedding ceremony.

title: Puram Kalithal
content: In the early morning of the wedding, the bride’s paternal aunt places neem leaves on her to ward off evil spirits.

title: Thirupootuthal - Tying of the Knot
content: The bride and groom are brought to the manai, where the groom ties the Kaluthiru around the bride’s neck with three knots. This ceremony is the official wedding, symbolizing the union of the couple and blessings for prosperity and happiness.

title: Isaipidimanam - Formal Marriage Agreement
content: After the Thirupootuthal, the fathers of the bride and groom register the wedding in the temple book, a traditional Chettiar practice.

title: Mamiyar and Nathanar Thiruputum Sadangu
description: Rituals welcoming the bride into the groom’s family
content: In this ritual, the groom’s mother and sister welcome the bride by blessing her with symbolic items like silver Lord Ganesha, turmeric, and rice.
